top_comment.text:
To everyone saying that Martina smelling her food is rude, if you watch any 
video where they are eating, she always smells it. It's just what she does. 
I don't find it rude at all. Hell, if it smells good, I'm gonna smell it. I 
feel it adds to the experience, especially when eating new food. And to the 
people saying they are weeaboos and rude foreigners, I'm vice president of 
the Japanese club at my school and I don't even know how to eat sushi, nor 
do I know the apparent customs of eating in a Japanese sushi restaurant. I 
wasn't raised eating sushi and neither were Martina and Simon (cause, you 
know, I live in the southern US and they lived in Canada) so of course none 
of us would know how to properly eat sushi. If I went to a sushi place and 
had the chef there help me out like the chef in this video did, I would be 
grateful, not offended. Cause I'd rather have someone tell me how to eat it 
instead of possibly offending someone by eating it wrong. And to the people 
saying the camera is too close to Simon's face, she was on her iPhone. And 
the black "fly" on the screen? Martina herself said it is a burnt out pixel 
in one of her comments.﻿

comments.author: Daigo Kawai

comments.text:
+Daigo Kawai What u are describing doesnt match with my experience at 
Jiro's or may be we look for a different experience when looking for sushi. 
When u say lack of services i think u are referring to that they dont offer 
tempura or anything that is not sushi, and that the menu is closed to what 
Jiro decides. The pace was perfect for me. The right amount of time to 
enjoy the sushi and served in the perfect order. again, the tamagoyaki was 
superb, Tako was extremely flavorful and tender, the wild kuruma shrimp 
delicious, and the Uni light years far from other restaurants i tried. We 
must agree that there is something special in the way Jiro makes sushi, but 
also the way is selected. 

Taira Shirokane is great, dont get me wrong, and hayashi is amazing, one of 
my tops so far, love the place but for some reason Jiro blew my mind. And 
that was before i saw  the documentary, as it was referred by one of my 
friends. I believe that now that Jiro is world famous people tries to make 
it look overrated.
comments.author: Himura Battousai

comments.text:
definitely. Jiro isn't well received in Tokyoite  foodies here at all. It 
has big time pros and cons, and cons are mostly due to its pace and the 
lack of services, and like most ginza sushi restaurants, it's overpriced 
for its worth. Jiro can be topped easily by so many other restaurants.

you should try Saito, Taira Shirokane and Hayashi. Waaaaay better than Jiro 
and Masa.

People are to greater or lesser extents xenophobic. We're evolved this way

+Edward Kwong Sashimi fish is never aged.  It's flash frozen when caught

comments.author: grumblekin

comments.text:
"It's raw fish with bits on". Is a filet just beef? Is a porterhouse just a 
steak? I would hope you'd say no. In the same way, sushi is NOT just raw 
fish. Yes, it is raw, but its safe to say not all fish/seafood are created 
equally. First, it's high quality fish. Meaning fish that was caught from a 
specific region known for the best tasting of that breed of fish. There's 
the preparation. Fish is aged much like beef. Not as long but it's aged to 
enhance the flavor. How you cut the fish makes a HUGE difference in 
texture. If you've ever filleted a fish, you'd know that you need a super 
sharp knife so that it's not only easier to cut, but to preserve the 
integrity if the fish. When you saw through something versus cutting, there 
is a huge difference. If you're disagreeing with anything i'm saying, I 
highly suggest you go read some food blogs or ask real chefs to educate 
yourself.

comments.text:
+aclock2 Respecting a culture and following what it has to offer are 
mutually inclusive, and this is specially true if it concerns a foreign 
one. 

As mentioned before, many people are downright uncomfortable with forking 
up a tip for the waiter after they've spent a substantial amount of money 
at an establishment. Others are equally as uncomfortable turning their 
phones off at a dinner table, or in in a theater. However, in neither 
scenario is your discomfort a justification for disrespect; you pay the 
waiter because that is the custom, you turn your phone off at the dinner 
table because it distracts the people at the table, and you turn your phone 
off at the theater because you ruin the experience for everyone else. It's 
called basic fucking courtesy.

If a chef doesn't want you to sniff his food, you simply don't sniff his 
food, or better yet, don't eat there at all. In Japanese culture, sniffing 
food is equivalent to seasoning something a chef has cooked - you're 
calling his/her creation shit. You just don't do it. If you fail to follow 
it, they throw your disrespectful arse out of there.

On a happier note, I'm delighted to hear that ilk of your kind would be 
discouraged from following or taking part in a culture that threatens to 
throw you out of a fine dinning experience for your failure to follow their 
rules. You've saved us all valuable time. Just let the rest of your kind 
know that as well, so that we can actually serve people who are interested 
in a proper experience.
comments.author: Thurman Ulrich

comments.text:
+Thurman Ulrich
The amount of fck given "    "
Respecting a culture and following everything it requires are completely 
different things. I refuse to follow things I'm not comfortable with even 
if it's in my own culture. Moreover, I would personally never follow 
anything from a culture that require you to follow it or get thrown out.
comments.author: aclock2

I really hate the argument that culture dictates something that makes no 
sense. If it is more efficient or safer to eat something a certain way, 
damn the tradition or culture. Taste is connected directly to scent. I'm 
flabbergasted that chefs or really anyone gives a damn. News flash, just 
because it's in a culture doesn't mean it's useful or even makes sense. We 
don't agree with cultures that kill people as part of ritual, but when it 
comes to non-harmful yet asinine things, we excuse it as "culture".

It just sounds snooty. I think it's obvious if someone is checking for 
poison or something vs taking in how awesome and fresh something smells.

If someone is truly offended by something, it's THEIR job to tell this 
person kindly not to do it. There is nothing wrong with that, even if 
logically it make not make sense, it's still respectful, not to the 
culture, but that human being with feelings to respect how they feel.

comments.text:
Well, Dulce wasn't talking about smelling food in general in the first 
place, but she just mentioned the specific way Martina smelled as "that 
way." I can relate to her because certainly Martina's quick sniffing look 
rude to me. 

On another note, traditional sushi culture in Japan considers the act of 
sniffing very rude as a mark of distrust to the chef or to the restaurant. 
Because due to the fact that most sushi include raw seafood which can be 
"fishy" quite easily, they are not supposed to smell at all other than 
subtle scent of vinegar which gets rid of the fishy smell. I was a sushi 
chef once and I believe all the sushi chefs out there are highly conscious 
about it. So, as for sushi in Japan, the smell/scent part is not expected 
to be enjoyed except for few such as broiled one.

But. Martina had been polite overall, or at least I could tell she never 
meant any offense to anyone, so... I bet the chef felt the same as me 
seeing their curiosity and appreciation.

take in as many senses as you can. Smell is a main part of how food tastes, 
and when the food is prepared to be enjoyed with such a fine palette, you 
should expect the consumer to smell the food to get the full experience. 
they create the food to be aseptically pleasing to as many senses as 
possible, and smell happens to be one of them. The moral of the story is, 
when you are at a regular eating establishment, don't smell the damn food, 
it is rude, but when you are at such a high class place where you are 
expected taste the distinct flavor from each component of the food, smell 
your food if you want.

broke university student that can only afford cheap all you can eat sushi)

pace giving you time to eat each piece set. The course can range from 15 
small servings to 30 or even more but you have to remember this is only 
done is high class sushi restaurants where it usually costs hundreds of 
dollars per head. In the more affordable sushi restaurants you have to 
order which ones you like from a menu and you get charged per item or per

It's food. Pick up food. Place food in mouth. Chew. Swallow. Repeat if

If you drink coffee with a straw, are you drinking it wrong.

top_comment.text:
actually real wasabi isn't hot at all, wasabi (if you can even call it 
that) that you buy from a super market isn't even real wasabi its like a 
mixture of horse radish and other ingredients, in fact 95% of wasabi you 
buy from stores isn't real wasabi because it takes too long to manufacture, 
real wasabi needs 3 - 4 years to fully mature, real wasabi needs extremely 
specific conditions to grow, it needs to be in a river bed with trees over 
hanging it, that's why when you look up real wasabi and see how much it is, 
you under stand that $500 - $1000 dollars for wasabi isn't so much for how 
much work is needed to produce it ;) p.s your very lucky to be able to 
taste real wasabi ahahha, that's why it wasn't hot because real wasabi 
isn't, it supposed to taste like it was meant to be with the fish your 
tasting, its suppose to complement it not take away the taste of the fish 
through burning hotness. ﻿

comments.text:
Um, yeah it is. It's pizza, it's just *different*. There's the Korean take 
on pizza, the Italian take on pizza, the North American take on pizza, it's 
just a fact of life that people have different takes on the "traditional" 
way of doing things. Look at all of the different ways the hamburger is 
taken around the world! No one goes around saying, "that's not a *real* 
hamburger. You only get *real* hamburgers from Connecticut made exactly 
this way."
Just let people enjoy food. Not everyone is as nit-picky as you are about 
food.
If you're Italian, who's to say a Japanese person can't come up to your 
oh-so-fabulous restaurant and say you're doing it wrong simply because 
you're Italian? That's what you're saying about American pizza. I can 
almost guarantee that there is something that your restaurant does that 
they don't do in Japan because of differences in resources and fish species 
by region.
By the way, I have never been to Italy but I have been to other European 
countries and I see PLENTY of obese people. Just sayin'  
I just don't understand what you're so upset about. This professional sushi 
chef is preparing sushi for them, telling them what it is, they eat it and 
enjoy it, end of story. What in the world is there to get offended about? 
THEY HAVE NO IDEA WHAT GOES INTO THIS BLAH BLAH BLAH THEY MAY HAVE NEVER 
TRIED THIS ANYWHERE ELSE TO COMPARE BLAH BLAH BLAH. You bet your bottom 
dollar that most of the people that come into your restaurant are the same 
way as Simon and Martina. 
I feel like there may be some misunderstanding due to the language barrier 
about what I said before, so I feel like you may have misunderstood some of 
my statements and that's why you're so offended. But whatever, let bygones 
be bygones. 
PS: I'm not a fella ;)

comments.text:
They're from Toronto and Toronto definitely has some authentic sushi, and 
I'm sure they've had it. Yes, they knew what they were eating but they 
didn't film all of it because they didn't find it necessary.
Anyway, does one really need to be a food connoisseur to know what they are 
eating is delicious? Your logic doesn't really make sense to me. They 
aren't food critics and they don't mean to be really, they are just going 
to restaurants to show them off and say, hey! I had a really good 
experience here because we, ourselves, liked the food! They aren't 
professional culinary critics by any means, they are just going to Japan 
and sharing their adventures and experience.
So, are you saying that an American can't go to Italy and try pizza and 
decide that they don't like it because American pizza is made differently? 
That's pretty shallow, if you ask me. You're probably thinking, "Their 
pizza isn't *real* pizza because they make it differently." So what if it's 
made differently? If it's delicious to the person does it really matter? 
What would the world be like if everyone made all the same food all the 
same way wherever you went and never experimented? Boring.

comments.text:
Forgive me but that is Total Bullshit. 

Clearly you've never had sushi..or at least if you think you have it was 
deep fried in a vat of bacon grease -_- Saying that sushi is the same as a 
regular fish you'd find at a market is the most juvenile not to mention 
idiotic mistake anyone, even people who don't like sushi could make. 

The 2 huge and obvious differences between sushi grade & regular grade fish 
are 1.) WHEN & HOW the fish was caught. Regular Fish you'd find at a market 
was most likely caught & immediately shoved into ice to be shipped off. 
Sushi grade however (depending on freshness) is normally kept in really 
clean tanks still swimming until ready to be eaten or prepared (to be 
fillet) & 2.) Is WHERE you cut the fish. You CANNOT just cut any part of a 
regular fish and serve it up raw because the fish IS ALREADY DEAD DUMBASS! 

I don't know about you but I'm not too keen on slicing into a whole fish 
that's been dead with a side of Freezer Burn (& not to mention without any 
proper training of slicing said fish in the first place) & serving ANY part 
of it to myself or my family. That's pretty damn stupid if you think that's 
ok. 

Sushi grade fish has been carefully sliced in SPECIFIC places that are safe 
for human consumption IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE FISH WAS CAUGHT. Freshness is 
key to Sushi Grade fish, & even in America isn't the freshest sushi in the 
world. 

It's just like Philly CheeseSteak Sandwich. WHERE WOULD U GO FOR THE 
BEST???? UHM YEA. DUH. PHILLY! or a New York Cheesecake???? 
NEW.FRICKIN.YORK. WHY? Because they originated there. Now where in the 
world do you think Sushi originated from? Take a wild guess. Yea Japan. 
Japanese people have been making & perfecting sushi for centuries!!! That's 
why it's so popular. 

And because they don't make ignorant mistakes like people like you. -_- 
Soak up a little culture into your brain before your mouth runs.
comments.author: JessiDatAsianGurl

comments.author: dolphin

comments.text:
+progresive house love  it's clearly obvious that you do not understand 
steps that are involved in preparing sushi. Sushi isn't about raw fish 
itself. If you watch the movie (jiro: dream of sushi), you get to 
understand different restaurants have their own way of marinating and aging 
fish (for tuna, they age between 3-5 days) .This aging process at 
temperature/salinity/marination is what brings out the flavor of fish to 
the max. Think of it as dry aging process of steak.

then comes to perfect balance of fish, rice and soy sauce. How you prepare 
the rice also dictates the flavor of sushi as well.  Food can be considered 
an art. For same reason you pay more to listen to Leon Fleisher play piano 
vs some local HS kid playing it.   to untrained ears, they may sound same 
and you might as well not pay more to listen to Mr. Fleisher, but if you 
can discern it, then you know the difference.

same for sushi.
comments.author: WON LEE

comments.author: dolphin

comments.text:
+progresive house love You don't get it.

They don't just use "some local bay salmon". Meat tastes different 
depending on fat content, fat marbleization and the food the animal ate. 

Let's say the perfect salmon would have a fat content of 35% (just an 
example) but the average of fat content would be like 20%. 

Sure there would be a tiny chance that you find a 35% fish yourself...but 
that is like winning the lottery if you just put out a fishing line. 

They fish hundreds or thousands of those fish...and only the 1% of fish 
that have the perfect grade will be sold for the high price to exclusive 
places that can afford them. 

Same fucking thing for beef. Fat content, marbleization and what they ate 
all change the taste of the meat. 
That's why a cow that was only fed certain herbs and was ensure to reach a 
certain bodyfat % will taste way better than some mass produced 5$ per 
pound piece of meat.

But again...you fail to realize that these FACTS all change the taste of 
meat products. If you compare quality meat to mass caught/mass produced 
meat next to each other you will even see the difference. 

Color, fat, marble...it all looks different.

captions.text: Guys, you have never had sushi this good in your life.
You're rubbing it into everyone's face.
Ok so we're going for sushi
we looked for a recommendation from someone we know that
can recommend a favourite sushi restaurant
and they've actually been to Jiro Sushi
which we've been told is not as good as this place
This is supposedly the best sushi he has ever had in his life
and Martina's camera died, so we have to use the bug camera
It's been seasoned a little bit too.
Guys, that was just about the best piece of octopus I've ever had in my life.
If octopus is always that delicious, I'm just gonna eat it right out of the water next time.
Left one: Wasabi and soy sauce.
So they're actually telling us how we're supposed to eat this, as we go.
I have no idea how I'm gonna go for regular sushi ever again.
I'm so ruined. Like, what am I going to do with my life now?
They've got like, a little glass case.
I don't wanna eat your piece.
Oh I see how this is.
Oh my god. It's ok. Shh, it's ok.
This is some of the - like seriously, you haven't tried this yet - this is some of the smoothest, creamiest, butteriest -
Ok, just take it from me. No, I don't wanna listen to this.
Do you not want to cry now?
I could just eat a whole plate of that.
This is like, the smoothest, creamiest -
I don't like recording you, because I have to wait.
So this is sea urchin. I've never actually liked sea urchin
Ok, ready? Don't make fun of me, ok?
How do you feel right now?
Very very oily, wasabi not spicy.
We, like, have the best life ever.
That is a LOT of wasabi.
And especially since it's ACTUAL wasabi; real.
This should be scaldingly, burning hot;
They said because it's so oily, it counteracts the spiciness.
That is, like, some of the oiliest, juiciest fish I've ever had
But the wasabi cuts through it, like a lemon, almost
The wasabi is like a compliment to it rather than just like a "Imma burn you in your face" kinda taste - which is what I like, but
This is a whole new addition. Oh my god.
I didn't even know there were parts of the fish that you could eat that were that fatty. Oh yeah.
So they actually make the wasabi
on a board made of shark skin.
I wonder if I could eat that straight. Like just take a bite.
What am I doing with myself?
Have you ever seen a piece of tuna sushi that shiny?
Earlier on he put a split in it and I can see  it's for bending
This is amazing because he didn't actually put it on my plate
he just, like, gave it to me in my hand
It's like a scallop, right? Like a really nice one
They will tell you otherwise, I think.
You're not gonna like this one.
You always say that when you wanna eat my food
This is - I've had chu toro before, it's one of the best pieces I've ever had.
I can't wait to see what it's like. I'm drooling.
This is like, a lifetime achievement about to be unlocked
I've only seen it talked about in anime before
If I ate your piece, would you divorce me?
Best piece of sushi I've ever had in my entire life.
This is uhh, eel with salt
Ok I think I embarassed myself last time cos I might have cried in front of them
So this is a golden eye red snapper
He says it's very very oily so he put a lot of wasabi in the middle
and then on top, there's a wasabi and like a daikon radish
and then he put a little bit of soy sauce
and then he actually dripped some lime juice
We've been eating for 2 hours, almost.
I mean, EVERTHING has been delicious.
I didn't eat anything that I said, "Oh, I don't like it."
We have one more course coming up
We actually told them that we were full and we wanna stop,
but then when we told him that we wanted to stop,
He looked so sad, and he's like, "Last one!"
So I think he's pulling out the big guns for this one
He actually didn't put it on the board. He just gave it to us in our hands
It's VERY soft. Like, I can feel it falling apart
That's the last one he wanted.
Oh, he gave it to me via hand as well
Ok, so this is the last one
And there's a tiny wasabi hidden on the inside
This is one of the best experiences of my life.
